clinical_study.brief_title: Furosemide Versus Ethacrynic Acid in Children With Congenital Heart Disease
clinical_study.official_title: Phase III Study of Furosemide Continuous Infusion Versus Ethacrynic Acid Continuous Infusion in Children Undergoing Cardiac Surgery: Randomized Double Blind Controlled Clinical Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: Bambino Gesù Hospital and Research Institute

clinical_study.source: Bambino Gesù Hospital and Research Institute

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to verify if ethacrynic acid continuous infusion is superior to furosemide continuous infusion in total urine output production during the first 24 post operative hours.

detailed_description.textblock:
Diuretic therapy in children after open heart surgery is widely administered, though no evidence currently supports if an ideal drug or an ideal dosage can be recommended. Loop diuretics are the most effective drugs in terms of urine output production but may cause some collateral effects such as metabolic alkalosis, hypovolemia, hypokalemia, ototoxicity. Furthermore, some reports showed that loop diuretics usage can be associated with an increased risk of renal dysfunction and mortality. However, their use in children with signs of fluid overload, pulmonary edema or oliguria is mandatory and widely practiced.
Furosemide and ethacrynic acid are often prescribed and administered without any specific indication, basing on clinicians preferences.
No study so far, explored the hypothesis of which of these drugs is the most effective in terms of urine output production and safe in terms of renal function.
This study aims to verify if ethacrynic acid continuous infusion is superior to furosemide continuous infusion in total urine output production during the first 24 post operative hours.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Mean total urine output production in the first post-operative day
primary_outcome.time_frame: first 24 hours after Intensive Care Unit admission
primary_outcome.description: Verification of the superiority of ethacrynic acid compared with furosemide in improving patients' total urine output by at least 1 ml/kg/h in the first 24 post-operative hours

secondary_outcome.time_frame: first 72 hours after Intensive Care Unit admission
secondary_outcome.description: Verification of the superiority of ethacrynic acid compared with furosemide in improving patients' renal function (asessed as creatinine, NGAL and pRIFLE score) in the first 72 post-operative hours

arm_group.description: furosemide, 0.2 mg/kg/h up to 0.8 mg/kg/h for 72 hours
ethacrynic acid, 0.2 mg/kg/h up to 0.8 mg/kg/h for 72 hours

intervention.description: furosemide, intravenous, continuous infusion, 0.2 mg/kg/h for 24 hours
ethacrynic acid, intravenous, continuous infusion, 0.2 mg/kg/h for 24 hours

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Children with congenital heart disease undergoing cardiac surgery
- intraoperative aortic cross clamp over 90 minutes or interventional catheterization procedures with post-operative inotrope score over 20
- sign of fluid retention after surgical procedures
Exclusion Criteria:
- Preoperative renal dysfunction
- Preoperative administration of more than 4mg/kg/die loop diuretics
- Need for renal replacement therapy at ICU admission
- Need for ECMO at ICU admission
